content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Book a highly-rated hotel with a swimming pool and free WiFi near the Louvre Museum in Paris for the weekend of March 3-5, 2024.  Please interact with https://www.booking.com/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: To start booking a hotel near the Louvre Museum in Paris, I first need to enter the destination in the search box. The appropriate text box is labeled [14] "Where are you going?".
Action: Type [14]; Louvre Museum, Paris
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.1
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is currently displaying September and October 2025, but I need to select the weekend of March 3-5, 2024. I need to keep navigating the calendar to go back to March 2024.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; up
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.15
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is showing dates for 2025, but I need March 2024. I should look for an option to go back several months to reach the correct date, but only a "Next month" button ([18]) is visible, and no "previous" button. Scrolling didn't change this. I need to look further for a way to access earlier months.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; up
Confidence: 0.85
Completion: 0.15
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The webpage is still showing the calendar for September and October 2025, and there is only a "Next month" button but no visible way to go back to March 2024. The destination is also set incorrectly to "Niagara Falls" instead of "Louvre Museum, Paris." I should update the destination to reflect the correct location for the given task.
Action: Type [13]; Louvre Museum, Paris
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar pop-up is still showing only future months, and no option to go to previous months is visible. The destination is stuck on "Niagara Falls" and didn't update. It looks like the Paris search was not entered or did not process. I should clear the textbox and enter "Louvre Museum, Paris" again with more emphasis, as it is key for the task. I'll try refocusing on the destination input.
Action: Type [13]; Louvre Museum, Paris
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.22
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The destination is still stuck as "Niagara Falls" and the calendar only allows moving forward (not backward to March 2024). This suggests either a UI state bug or the need to reset the search. Clicking the "Stays" tab could reset the search form for a fresh start tailored to the task needs.
Action: Click [7]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.23
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search box has been reset, but "Niagara Falls" is still in the destination field. I should delete the existing text and enter "Louvre Museum, Paris" as the destination to begin a relevant search for the task.
Action: Type [14]; Louvre Museum, Paris
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.25
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar and search field have reverted to showing "Niagara Falls," not "Louvre Museum, Paris." Calendar navigation is still stuck on future dates, and the change of destination didn't register. The best chance to proceed is to try clearing/deleting the current text in the destination input to force an update.
Action: Type [13]; Louvre Museum, Paris
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.26
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The system is still stuck on "Niagara Falls" in the destination field, and the calendar is stuck in late 2025 (far past the needed dates). To correct the destination, it's essential to clear the incorrect location from the textbox first, which may allow a new entry to be recognized and processed.
Action: Type [13]; 
Confidence: 0.97
Completion: 0.28
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The "Where are you going?" textbox [13] is now empty and ready for input, with the prompt "Enter a destination to start searching." This is the correct place to enter "Louvre Museum, Paris" for a relevant search.
Action: Type [13]; Louvre Museum, Paris
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Although I previously typed in "Louvre Museum, Paris," the destination has reverted to "Niagara Falls." It seems that clicking to confirm the new search or manually selecting from suggestions might be necessary. Since "Louvre Museum, Paris" isn’t being accepted directly into the field, trying the search might push the new entry through.
Action: Click [99]
Confidence: 0.85
Completion: 0.32
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The destination is still stuck as "Niagara Falls" and not allowing changes, even after trying to search. The calendar remains fixed in 2025. The "Where are you going?" field [13] appears as an input box; I should try clicking it to trigger a destination selection dropdown or allow clearing.
Action: Click [13]
Confidence: 0.92
Completion: 0.32
